handouts.title: Acne
handouts.description: Overview, causes, skincare, diet, lifestyle, and product guide.
handouts.content:
What Is Acne?

Acne is a common skin condition that affects the hair follicles and oil glands in your skin. It happens when pores become clogged with oil, dead skin cells, and bacteria. Acne is NOT caused by poor hygiene or dirty skin!

What Causes Acne?

Acne develops from four main factors working together:

  • Excess oil production in your skin
  • Clogged pores from dead skin cells
  • Bacteria (called C. acnes) that live on the skin
  • Inflammation (redness and swelling)

Hormones, genetics, and certain medications can make acne worse.

Skincare Habits

  • Wash your face gently, twice daily – Use a fragrance-free cleanser. Avoid harsh scrubs, astringents, or exfoliating washes, as these can irritate your skin and worsen acne.
  • Use a moisturizer – A fragrance-free, non-comedogenic (won't clog pores) moisturizer helps reduce irritation from acne medications. Apply before and/or after topical medications (sandwich method) to minimize dryness.
  • Choose the right makeup – Look for products labeled "non-comedogenic," "oil-free," or "won't clog pores."
  • Clean brushes and makeup utensils regularly – Bacteria and oils accumulate on these items.
  • Remove makeup thoroughly before bed – Sleeping in makeup can clog pores and worsen acne.
  • Apply sunscreen daily – Use a broad-spectrum SPF 30 or higher, especially if you have dark spots from acne. Sun exposure can darken these spots and make them last longer.
  • Avoid touching your face – Hands transfer bacteria and oils to facial skin throughout the day.
  • Don't pick, pop, or squeeze – Picking at acne can cause scarring, infection, and worsen dark spots!

Diet Considerations

Research on diet and acne is still evolving, but some studies suggest:

  • Consider a low-glycemic diet – Foods that cause rapid spikes in blood sugar (white bread, sugary drinks, candy, white rice, pastries) may worsen acne. High glycemic foods increase insulin and IGF-1 levels, which stimulate oil production and inflammation. Choosing whole grains, vegetables, and lean proteins may help.
  • Dairy may play a role – Studies show an association between milk consumption and acne. If you notice a connection, consider reducing dairy intake.
  • Omega-3 fatty acids may help – Foods rich in omega-3s (salmon, sardines, walnuts, flaxseed) have anti-inflammatory properties that may benefit skin health.
  • Chocolate – Evidence is mixed; cocoa or high-sugar formulations may worsen acne in some people.

Lifestyle Factors

  • Get regular exercise – Studies show that regular physical activity may indirectly improve acne through metabolic and stress-related effects.
  • Limit prolonged sitting – Sedentary behavior has been associated with acne in some observational studies, though causation is unclear.
  • Prioritize sleep – Going to bed late and poor sleep quality have been linked to acne. Aim for consistent sleep.
  • Change/wash pillowcases regularly – Oils, bacteria, and dead skin cells accumulate on pillowcases.
  • Clean your phone screen, hats, and glasses – Objects that touch your face frequently can transfer bacteria and oils.
  • Manage stress – Stress can worsen acne through hormonal changes.

Important Reminders – Understanding Your Treatment!

  • Results take time – be consistent with your habits for at least 2–3 months before evaluating improvement.
  • Everyone's skin is different – what works for one person may not work for another.
  • Use sunscreen daily (SPF 30+)
  • ALWAYS SPOT TEST NEW PRODUCTS! Avoid using multiple new products at once!
  • DO NOT PICK AT ACNE! AVOID TOUCHING FACE!

handouts.title: Accutane (Isotretinoin)
handouts.description: Oral isotretinoin: how it works, side effects, iPLEDGE, and requirements.
handouts.content:
What Is Accutane?

Isotretinoin is a prescription medication used to treat severe nodular acne that has not responded to other treatments, including antibiotics. It is taken by mouth in two divided doses with food. The dose is based on your body weight, and a typical course of treatment lasts about 4 to 5 months or longer depending on your response to treatment.

Isotretinoin (Accutane) works by:

  • Significantly reducing oil production in your skin
  • Decreasing inflammation
  • Preventing clogged pores
  • Reducing acne-causing bacteria

Side Effects

Important: Side effects are dose-dependent and reversible after stopping the medication.

Common:

  • Dry skin and lips – Apply a fragrance-free moisturizer frequently throughout the day. Use a thick lip balm or petroleum jelly (Vaseline®, Aquaphor®) on lips multiple times daily. Avoid hot showers and harsh soaps.
  • Dry eyes – Use preservative-free artificial tears throughout the day. Consider removing contact lenses if dryness becomes uncomfortable.

Less common but reported:

  • Joint and muscle aches
  • Mood changes
  • Nosebleeds (due to dry nasal passages)
  • Increased sun sensitivity — use sunscreen daily (SPF 30 or higher)
  • "Purging": temporary worsening of acne during the first few weeks of treatment
  • Elevated cholesterol, triglycerides, or liver enzymes (monitored with blood tests)

What To Expect During Treatment

  • Acne may temporarily worsen during the first 2–4 weeks ("purging") — this is expected and not a reason to stop treatment
  • Most patients see noticeable improvement by 2–3 months
  • Many patients experience long-term acne remission after completing a full course
  • Maintenance topical therapy is often recommended after completion
  • 8–20% of patients may require a second course if acne returns

While On Treatment, DO NOT

  • Donate blood during treatment or for 1 month after stopping
  • Share your medication with anyone
  • Cosmetic skin procedures (waxing, dermabrasion, laser treatments) during treatment or for 6 months after (risk of scarring)
  • Take vitamin A supplements (may cause additive toxic effects)
  • Take tetracycline antibiotics (e.g., doxycycline), as this combination can increase intracranial pressure

iPLEDGE Program Enrollment (Required)

All patients must be enrolled in the iPLEDGE Program, a mandatory FDA safety program designed to prevent pregnancy while taking isotretinoin.

Why is this important? Isotretinoin causes severe birth defects if taken during pregnancy. The risk of miscarriage is about 20%, and the risk of birth defects is 18% to 28%.

  • Enrollment is required before starting treatment
  • Must sign informed consent forms
  • FASTING laboratory studies (cholesterol, triglycerides, liver tests) must be completed within 5 days prior to next appointment, which is scheduled in 1 month

For Patients Who Can Become Pregnant:

  • Two pregnancy tests are required before starting treatment
  • A negative pregnancy test is REQUIRED on the day of enrollment
  • Options include: In-office pregnancy test ($15), OR Home pregnancy test — email photo to: marissacalderm@icloud.com (photo must include: date of test, Government ID, and negative test result)
  • The second pregnancy test will be included with laboratory work completed within 5 days prior to your next appointment
  • Two forms of contraception are required — begin 1 month before starting treatment, continue during treatment, continue for 1 month after stopping isotretinoin

Monthly Treatment Requirements (IMPORTANT)

  • Monthly office visit or telehealth visit is required
  • In-office and virtual visits may alternate if scheduling is difficult
  • Laboratory monitoring: Checked approximately every 3 months (may be checked more frequently if clinically indicated)
  • Patients who can become pregnant: Monthly pregnancy testing is mandatory — test must confirm NEGATIVE

Additional Resources

  • iPLEDGE Program: www.ipledgeprogram.com | 1-866-495-0654
  • American Academy of Dermatology: www.aad.org

Reminder: Isotretinoin is a highly effective medication when used correctly. Most side effects are temporary and manageable. Strict adherence to pregnancy prevention requirements, monthly visits, and laboratory monitoring is essential for safe and successful treatment. Please contact your healthcare provider with any questions or concerns during treatment.
